text: that Norman Smith is there Wow Norman
what does this mean this is potentially
a massive blow to Teresa Mays brexit
plans because the Lord Chief Justice
says he wasn't taking a position in
terms of whether we should be in or
outside the EU purely on a point of law
he rejected the government's argument
that the government should trigger
article 50 in other words it should be
left to ministers to decide when we
leave the EU instead he backed the
claimants case which was no it should be
Parliament that decides now that opens
up a nightmare scenario for the
government potentially it means that
Parliament could have to pass
legislation to trigger article 15 if
that was the case the whole process
could last for months and months and
months because it wouldn't just have to
go through the Commons it would have to
go through the House of Lords to where
the government does not have a majority
and where there are an overwhelming
number of peers opposed to brexit on top
of that to add to the government's
potential nightmare is the possibility
that MPs could seek to amend that
legislation to bid in all sorts of
conditions on brexit for example they
might insist that MP should have another
vote on Teresa Mays negotiating strategy
perhaps they might put in an amendment
saying that we should remain a part of
the single market this has thrown one
almighty spanner in the works for Teresa
May the one glimmer the government will
hang on to is the possibility of going
to the Supreme Court to appeal against
this decisions but at the moment I would
think in Downing Street they're holding
their head in the hands thinking what do
we do now and on that is it clear that
they will have leave to appeal to the
Supreme Court oh yeah this is such a
huge constitutional issue they will have
automatic right to leapfrog the Court of
Appeal and goes straight to the Supreme
Court here's one little quirk Flo it is
possible though unlikely that the final
decision could be taken by the European
Court of Justice now that
be an extraordinary scenario where our
future in Europe was determined by the
European Court so I think no one is
going to want to do that although
legally that would be possible but I
would imagine there will be an appeal
unless the government decide okay let's
just go for the vote quickly and see if
we can do it on a simple what's called
substantive motion a one-off vote in the
House of Commons it gets a little bit
complicated but the two scenarios that
seemed to me to be appearing before the
government is can they just hold a
one-off substantive vote in the House of
Commons as sufficient to show Parliament
has been consulted or as the claimants
argue they have to introduce legislation
in other words there has to be an
article 50 bill which could take months
and months and months probably delayed
triggering article 50 maybe until you
know 2018 who knows and also opening up
the option of a whole load of difficult
and awkward amendments being chucked in
making the process of brexit much much
harder so the key thing now is could the
government go for a quick vote or are
they going to get bogged down in
legislation and and when you say good
because they go for a quick vote would
it be that simple how are mps likely to
respond you know if when they do get a
vote you know here's the funny thing
Jana the vote is not the problem I know
that sounds a bit odd but the reason is
this most MPs will vote to trigger
article 50 because not to do so would be
to spit in the face of the electorate
so even MPs who are committed remain as
opposed to brexit even a large number of
them would vote to trigger article 50
the issue is the way that boat is held
if it is held as a short sharp shock
vote in the next few weeks or a couple
of months then the government will
probably win it and Theresa May can
stick to a timetable of triggering
article 50 by the end of March if
however the judges rule that there has
to be legislation then the government
will have to bring forward a
bill to enact article 50 now legislation
takes months to get through Parliament
it is hugely convoluted problematic it
is a gift to opponents and so the issue
as I say is not the vote but how the
vote is going to be carried out either
as a short sharp substantive motion or a
long protracted difficult messy painful
piece of legislation
